introduction:
*own it own it own it own it...*
...
Ah, apologies, I was not expecting such esteemed guests this hour; no matter, we shall make time. I, King Mithradates IV, welcome you to the Kingdom of Pontus...
...
You haven't heard of my prestigious bloodline? Ah, remind me, did you say you were Persian or Greek?
neutralHello: What might I do for you friend...?
hateHello: Oh my Gods... I'm speechless. Absolutely dumbfounded. What could drive so many foreigners to butcher innocent people, their friends, neighbors, countrymen, just because they spoke a similar tongue to your's? I'm sorry beyond words, truly. We've had a couple squabbles in the past, but you must've understood, I mean you can't have thought me so cruel or insane that I could let stand such an atrocity; and by those that acted as if they were your allies, I mean I don't even feel like I know this peninsula now. I promise I'll do everything I can to see these regional ethnic massacres end at once. A tragedy, really. My deepest condolences.
tradeRequest: For you, I offer the riches of the Silk Road.

uniqueText: When going to war war, enemies should possibly suffer a number of disruptions: CS influence will d√©grade 15% faster for all other civs, Pontic units may find an opportunity to attack twice, with luck enemy cities will suffer halved growth, and no matter how lucky you are rebel units will not start spawning in enemy land cause that don't fucking work rn. +10% [Gold] in Costal cities during Golden Ages. +33% Production towards melee units during WLTKD.

introduction: I welcome you foreigner, as King Midas of Phrygia, though I'm sure my reputation precedes me.
name: Phrygia
neutralHello: Welcome, foreign dignitary. What is it you've come to offer?
startIntroPart1: Phrygians were kinda very vaguely remenicent of the Thracians but linguistically Greeks closest relative. They migrated at the very end of the bronze age just to prod at the rapidly expiring Hittites. Had good music and ok hats like the Thracians. Adaptable group of fellows, skilled at working iron but especially gold. Decent horsemen idk. Midas gold man Phrygian. Gordian knot it was in fucking Gordia. Vanilla Anatolii w/Thracian infusion. Cybele is cool besides the castration, Magna Mater was a real downgrade. Oh yeah and Midas was credited w/black lead or something, which kinda j sounds worse than what he actually did.
tradeRequest: I assure you, a handshake is all that it's gonna take for us to make you a fabulous amount of wealth.

startIntroPart1: Money they're rich you know this shit. Honestly there's nothing else they seemed to exceed in or that characterized them. Creating currency and become rich is cool but really compared to the huge philosophically, mathematically, and politically advanced shit the Greeks were mowing through its kinda eh. On top of that Lydia was exponentially less colorful culturally, and just got railed by Persia like the rest of Anatolia. Then posthumously by Phrygia. Dunno

attacked:
You people never learn. Isauria is ours and so are your sheep. 
I'd see our cities burned to ash before submitting it to you.
declaringWar: I grow sick of you foreigners looking down on us. I think I will take your throne and look down upon you.
hateHello: I'll rip your fucking head off.
introduction:
Hnh? We are the Isaurians; last of the true Anatolians, unconquered by Persia, unbroken by Macedon, a people as strong as uncompromising as the mountains we inhabit. 
Diplomacy is over now, get out
name: Isauria
startIntroPart1: Kolechia borders five other countries, a lake with Antegria and Obristan, and the easternmost ocean. Kolechia is the largest of the three countries seen in their entirety on the map.
tradeRequest: This once, we are willing to negotiate a deal. And not for the purpose of distraction while we steal your sheep.
uniques: [+50]% Strength for cities <with [1] to [6] neighboring [Mountain] tiles>
[+40]% Strength decreasing with distance from the capital <when fighting units from a Civilization with more Cities than you> <for [Melee] units>
[+1 Production, +1 Food] from [Mountain] tiles [in all cities] <when at war>
Land units may cross [Mountain] tiles after the first [Great General] is earned
uniqueText: +2 [Production] from Mountain tiles, plus +1 [Production] +1 [Food] when at war. +40% Strength for Melee units decreasing with distance from the capital when fighting larger civilizations. +50% Strength for cities next to a mountain.

attacked: An opportunity to fight beside true friends is the best suprise we could've asked for.
declaringWar: We've built cities and learned Greek, but our blood is Thracian. Seems you've forgotten that
defeated: My final decree, I bequeath my kingdom to Rome, and to Julius Caesar, Queen of Bithynia.

introduction: Ave, you stand before King Nicomedes IV of Bithynia, which, coincidentally, is also the name of this city. Now, sit you must try the wine here before you go.
name: Bithynia
neutralHello: How is going it over there?
startIntroPart1: Bithynia was founded by a Thracian-related tribe that moved into the area Southwest of Constantinople later than other tribes outside of the Galatians. They liked mercenaries. They liked Romans. Caesar bottom joke. Imagine living and dying in service of your people, and they end up primarily remembered for one of their kings, specifically for being rumored to have railed some guy by his political enemies. Anyways i don't remember how people talk sorry
tradeRequest: Know that trade strengthens all peoples involved.
uniques: [+1 Gold, +1 Culture] from each Trade Route <upon declaring friendship> <when not at war>
[2] free [Melee] units appear <upon declaring friendship> <when at war>
uniqueText: Upon declaring friendship, gain +1 [Gold] & +1 [Culture] from each trade route if at peace, or 2 free melee units if at war. Settling a city yields 25-100 [Gold], and gain +2 [Gold] from military buildings.
